item.title: Coronavirus: Lockdown easing to allow groups of six to meet
item.description: The PM says groups of up to six people will be able to meet outside in England from Monday.

item.title: George Floyd: National Guard deployed after Minneapolis clashes
item.description: State troops are activated after days of protests over the death of a black man in police custody.

item.title: Trump signs executive order targeting Twitter after fact-checking row
item.description: The US president's move follows a decision by Twitter to add a "fact-check" notice to his tweets.

item.title: Lion attack in Australia leaves zookeeper badly injured
item.description: The woman is being treated for critical injuries after the incident in New South Wales, authorities say.

item.title: Dominic Cummings 'might have broken lockdown rules' - police
item.description: Boris Johnson says the matter is closed - and prevents scientific advisers from being quizzed about it.

item.title: Coronavirus: UK's tenth - and possibly final - clap for carers
item.description: People across the UK showed their appreciation for front-line workers for the tenth week in a row.

item.title: Moscow more than doubles city's Covid-19 death toll
item.description: Officials now say 1,561 people died from the disease in April - not 639 as initially announced.

item.title: Coronavirus: How the virus is hitting some harder than others
item.description: The BBC’s Clive Myrie meets black and minority ethnic hospital staff and sees the impact the virus is having beyond the ward.

item.title: Premier League: BBC to show live matches when season resumes in June
item.description: Four Premier League games will be broadcast, free to air, live on BBC Sport when the season resumes in June.

item.title: Louise Smith: Man charged with murder of teenager
item.description: Shane Lee Mays is accused of killing Louise Smith, 16, who was found dead in a Hampshire woodland.

item.title: Gough Whitlam dismissal: Australian court grants access to Queen's letters
item.description: A historian argues they should be public record over the sacking of Australia's prime minister in 1975.

item.title: World's deepest octopus captured on camera
item.description: A "Dumbo" octopus is photographed at a depth of 7,000m in the Indian Ocean's Java Trench.

item.title: Men hired for sexual fantasy break into wrong house
item.description: The pair, hired for role play involving a broom, mistakenly went to the wrong house with machetes.

item.title: The Papers: 'Happy Monday' on the way and 'football's coming home'
item.description: Eased lockdown restrictions dominate Friday's newspapers - while Dominic Cummings remains in the spotlight.

item.title: Quiz of the Week: Why was Neighbours back in the news?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I built a memorial to my grandfather on Animal Crossing'
item.description: One young woman used popular game Animal Crossing for her family tradition of Bai San.

item.title: RuPaul's Drag Race season 12: The most political, troubled series ever?
item.description: The reality show has reminded US viewers to register to vote every week during its 12th season.

item.title: When Covid-19 hit, zookeeper Caitlin Henderson ended up in lockdown with 70 spiders
item.description: When Covid-19 hit, zookeeper Caitlin Henderson ended up in lockdown with 70 spiders.

item.title: Coronavirus: Is this the final hurrah for clap for carers?
item.description: The UK applauds carers on Thursday evening for what the event organiser says could be the last time.

item.title: Berlin monument to 1989 democracy heroes - in pictures
item.description: The bowl-shaped monument in the German capital is designed to move when enough people gather.

item.title: The African-American high fashion pioneer
item.description: The story of the little-known couturier who designed Jackie Kennedy's wedding dress

item.title: World's oldest man Bob Weighton dies, aged 112
item.description: Bob Weighton from Hampshire "died peacefully in his sleep, from cancer", his family confirms.

item.title: Biggest UK solar plant approved
item.description: Climate change: Go-ahead for controversial solar farm - the UK's biggest

item.title: Martin Scorsese reveals lockdown 'anxiety' and 'relief'
item.description: The US film director has made a haunting home video for the BBC about his experience of confinement.

item.title: The coronavirus conundrum when your mouth is your ‘hand’
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic becomes a different kind of challenge when you use your mouth as your ‘hands’.

item.title: The coronavirus 'class divide': Parents judged for school return choices
item.description: Parents of year six and year one pupils have been falling out over whether to send them back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will public toilets be reopened?
item.description: The lack of public loos has led to reports of visitors defecating in public spaces.

item.title: Coronavirus: How Turkey took control of Covid-19 emergency
item.description: Even without imposing a total lockdown, Turkey seems to have handled the outbreak well.

item.title: The films to look out for at the We Are One festival
item.description: Cannes, Toronto and Sundance are among the film festivals uniting for an online streaming event.

item.title: Rohingya refugee crisis: 'The bodies were thrown out of the boat'
item.description: Khadiza Begum, a Rohingya refugee, left Myanmar to escape violence but found more horror at sea.

item.title: Rolls-Royce: How serious is the latest jobs cull?
item.description: The aero-engine maker is cutting 9,000 jobs - but is there more bad news to come?

item.title: The little lights now packing a deadly punch
item.description: LEDs already light our houses but developments are making them even more powerful.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who are the contact tracers and what are they doing?
item.description: Doctors, call centre staff and students are some of the 25,000 people chasing Covid-19 cases in England.

item.title: Premier League set to restart on 17 June with Man City v Arsenal and Villa v Sheff Utd
item.description: The Premier League is set to restart on 17 June - more than three months after it was suspended because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Ennis-Hill 'honoured' to win best British women's sporting moment in BBC vote
item.description: Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill's heptathlon gold at London 2012 wins the best British women's sport moment in our vote.

item.title: Domestic cricket season delayed until 1 August because of coronavirus
item.description: The start of the domestic cricket season is delayed again, with no matches before 1 August because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Leicester offer long-term deal to Liverpool's Lallana - Friday's gossip
item.description: Leicester make a bid for Liverpool's Adam Lallana, five Premier League clubs want Philippe Coutinho, Gareth Bale will stay at Real Madrid, plus more.

item.title: Reducing scrums and speeding up rucks among 10 optional law trials approved by World Rugby
item.description: World Rugby approves optional law trials to help reduce the risk of coronavirus transmission in the sport.

item.title: 'A chance for people to get together' - AGF Aarhus use Zoom to create virtual grandstand
item.description: A giant virtual grandstand allowed AGF Aarhus to watch their side's Danish Superliga match against Randers through Zoom.

item.title: Coronavirus: NHS tracer or potential scammer, how will I know? And other questions
item.description: Spotting the difference between NHS contact tracers and scammers - and other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Fact-checking the row
item.description: Senior Conservatives are still questioning adviser's account of driving his family 260 miles during lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Guidelines to social contact are starting to change across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: How will contact tracing work in England?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to monitor who they have been near to combat coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What can you do in Scotland from Friday?
item.description: After almost 10 weeks of lockdown which restrictions are being eased - and which remain in force?

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Did he break lockdown rules?
item.description: The UK PM's most senior adviser has responded to accusations that he broke lockdown rules - what did he say?

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: When are schools reopening?
item.description: Which pupils can expect to be back in classrooms shortly - and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England next month, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: How to keep safe while shopping in a coronavirus pandemic
item.description: From one way systems to not touching everything on the shelves - shopping will look very different.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can it affect eyesight?
item.description: The prime minister's chief adviser says his vision was affected by coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on caring for children during lockdown?
item.description: A look at the guidance as Downing Street backs Dominic Cummings over his 260-mile lockdown trip.

item.title: Dominic Cummings row: The families who stayed away in lockdown
item.description: Members of the public have expressed anger after the PM's chief adviser travelled to Durham in lockdown.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Full statement on lockdown row
item.description: The PM's chief adviser told a press conference he wanted to "clear up confusion" amid calls for him to resign.

item.title: Could you have to pay your bank to save money?
item.description: As countries take extreme measures keep the economy afloat, could we see negative interest rates?

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe are takeaways and supermarket deliveries?
item.description: If coronavirus can be transferred on to surfaces, what are the risks of buying food?

item.title: What's the risk on public transport?
item.description: Bus and train operators are reducing services and increasing cleaning.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can children catch and pass on coronavirus?
item.description: BBC's Health Correspondent Laura Foster explains what we know currently about how children are affected by the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where do governments borrow money?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Amazon under threat: Fires, loggers and now virus
item.description: How the loss of the Amazon goes beyond deforestation - and what the nine countries that share this natural resource are doing to protect it.
